dataset_description.json.Name: Long-term Memory (LTM) for famous Faces, Places, and common Objects
dataset_description.json.Acknowledgements: This work was supported by NIH grant MH064498 (B.R.P.). The authors would like to thank Sean Polyn for his helpful suggestions and stimuli, and Ken Norman and his group at Princeton for providing insightful feedback on our analyses.

- DICOMS not available at the time of initial release.

build-bids-crc.README:
Build BIDS
=========
Scripts written by Chris Cox to compose BIDS directory from source
dataset. Code is highly project specific. 2018/09/03

Install
-------
These scripts are meant to be used from within the `BIDS/sourcedata`
directory, so copy or move them there.

Usage
-----
All `.sh` files can be sourced from `bash` or `zsh`.
All `.py` files can be source with python3.

Dependencies
------------
`bids_anat_deface.sh` depends on `pydeface`, which depends on `fsl` and
the python packages `nibabel`, `nipype`, and `numpy`.

README:
# Long-term Memory (LTM) for famous Faces, Places, and common Objects

Data were initially published by Jarrod A. Lewis-Peacock & Bradley R. Postle (2008) in the Journal of Neuroscience in an article titled "Temporary activation of long-term memory supports working memory". The fMRI data shared here are from the *stimulus judgment task*, also referred to as the "LTM task". This data has been reanalyzed and entered into BIDS format (1.1.0)  by Christopher R. Cox and Timothy T. Rogers. These data are published with the kind permission of Lewis-Peacock and Postle, and shared under the CC-BY license. "Licensees may copy, distribute, display and perform the work and make derivative works and remixes based on it only if they give the author or licensor the credits (attribution) in the manner specified by these."

The original work and image acquisition was supported by NIH grant MH064498 (B.R.P.).

If you use this data, please cite this paper: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2699183/", and reference the access key on **OpenNeuro**.

The related paper is open access, and describes all pertinent fMRI acquisition and task details.

## Slice acquisition details
The 30 axial slices were acquired in "alt+z" order. Assuming that the
first slice is **slice 0**, and lumping in 0 with the even numbers, "alt+z" order means that the even numbered slices are acquired first, in order of ascending z, followed by the odd numbered slices. See AFNI
documentation for 3dTshift for more detail.

sub-04_task-LTM_run-5_bold.json.TaskDescription:
Subjects viewed a total of 90 stimuli drawn from three categories: 30 famous
        people, 30 famous locations, and 30 common objects. They then indicated (on a
        four-point Likert scale, using a stimulus-response box) how much they
        liked the celebrity, how much they would like to visit the location, or how
        often they encountered the object in everyday life. Each stimulus was presented
        one time only, for a total of 90 randomly ordered stimulus presentations. Each
        LTM trial consisted of a cue period (2 s), a stimulus period (5 s), and a
        judgment period (3 s). After each trial, subjects performed an arithmetic task
        (16 s) to reduce interference between trials

onset.Description: Onset of the cue associated with each trial (in seconds).

duration.Description: An amount of time that corresponds to the cue, stimulus presentation, and judgment period.

label.Description: Indication of whether the trial involved a famous face, famous place, or common object
